How to Calculate Discounts: Never Overpay During a Sale Again

Master sale math in seconds. Learn how to calculate discount percentages, stacked discounts, and the real price after multiple markdowns.

üìë Table of Contents

  • Basic Discount Calculation
  • Stacked Discounts (The Tricky Part)
  • Finding the Original Discount Percentage
  • Sales Tax After Discount
  • ‚ÄùBuy One Get One‚Äù Deals Decoded
  • Calculate Any Discount Instantly
  • Frequently Asked Questions

Black Friday: ‚Äú70% OFF EVERYTHING!‚Äù You grab three items, head to checkout, and the total is somehow still $180. How is that possible? Understanding discount math protects your wallet from misleading sales tactics.

Basic Discount Calculation

The simplest discount calculation:

Sale Price = Original Price √ó (1 - Discount Rate)

Or if you prefer: Sale Price = Original Price - (Original Price √ó Discount %)

Example: A $95 jacket at 40% off:

  • $95 √ó (1 - 0.40) = $95 √ó 0.60 = $57
  • You save: $95 - $57 = $38

Quick shortcut: To find the price after discount, just multiply by the ‚Äúkeep‚Äù percentage:

  • 20% off ‚Üí multiply by 0.80
  • 25% off ‚Üí multiply by 0.75
  • 30% off ‚Üí multiply by 0.70
  • 40% off ‚Üí multiply by 0.60
  • 50% off ‚Üí multiply by 0.50

Stacked Discounts (The Tricky Part)

‚ÄúTake an extra 20% off already reduced items!‚Äù Sounds amazing, but the math isn‚Äôt what most people think.

The wrong way: 40% off + 20% off = 60% off ‚ùå

The right way: Apply each discount sequentially.

Example: $100 item, 40% off then extra 20% off:

  1. First discount: $100 √ó 0.60 = $60
  2. Second discount: $60 √ó 0.80 = $48
  3. Actual total discount: ($100 - $48) √∑ $100 = 52% off

That‚Äôs 52% off, not 60%. The difference adds up when you‚Äôre spending hundreds of dollars.

Quick formula for stacked discounts: Total discount = 1 - (first multiplier √ó second multiplier) = 1 - (0.60 √ó 0.80) = 1 - 0.48 = 52%

Finding the Original Discount Percentage

Sometimes you see a sale tag but want to know the actual percentage off:

Discount % = ((Original - Sale Price) √∑ Original) √ó 100

Example: Was $249, now $179:

  • ($249 - $179) √∑ $249 √ó 100 = 28.1% off

This is useful when stores just show the sale price without stating the percentage.

Sales Tax After Discount

Remember: sales tax is calculated on the discounted price, not the original price. That‚Äôs one small benefit of buying on sale.

Example: $80 item at 25% off in a state with 8% sales tax:

  • Discounted price: $80 √ó 0.75 = $60
  • Tax: $60 √ó 0.08 = $4.80
  • Total: $64.80

‚ÄùBuy One Get One‚Äù Deals Decoded

BOGO deals aren‚Äôt always 50% off:

  • BOGO Free ‚Äî Buy 1, get 1 free = 50% off if you buy exactly 2
  • BOGO 50% off ‚Äî Buy 1, get 1 at half price = 25% off per item
  • Buy 2 Get 1 Free ‚Äî 33% off per item (if you buy exactly 3)

The real question is whether you actually need the extra items. A ‚Äúdeal‚Äù on something you don‚Äôt need isn‚Äôt a deal ‚Äî it‚Äôs spending.

Calculate Any Discount Instantly

Skip the mental math. Our free discount calculator shows you the sale price, savings amount, and final price with tax in seconds. For more complex math, check out our percentage calculator.

‚ùì Frequently Asked Questions

How do I calculate 30% off a price? ‚ñº

Multiply the original price by 0.70 (which is 1 minus 0.30). For example, 30% off $80 = $80 √ó 0.70 = $56.

Does 50% off plus 20% off equal 70% off? ‚ñº

No. Stacked discounts are applied sequentially, not added. 50% off then 20% off means: $100 ‚Üí $50 ‚Üí $40. That's 60% off total, not 70%.

How do I find what percentage I'm saving? ‚ñº

Subtract the sale price from the original price, divide by the original price, multiply by 100. Example: was $120, now $84 ‚Üí (120-84) √∑ 120 √ó 100 = 30% off.

Is it a good deal if it's marked up before being discounted? ‚ñº

Watch out for inflated 'original' prices. Retailers sometimes raise prices before a sale to make discounts look bigger. Compare the sale price to what you'd normally expect to pay, not just the listed original price.
